 ``` By default, the expansion-panel header includes a toggle icon at the end of the header to indicate the expansion state. This icon can be hidden via the `hideToggle` property. content\_copy ``` ``` #### [link](https://material.angular.io/components/expansion/overview\#action-bar) Action bar Actions may optionally be included at the bottom of the panel, visible only when the expansion is in its expanded state. content\_copy ``` ``` #### [link](https://material.angular.io/components/expansion/overview\#disabling-a-panel) Disabling a panel Expansion panels can be disabled using the `disabled` attribute. A disabled expansion panel can't be toggled by the user, but can still be manipulated programmatically. content\_copy ``` ``` ### [link](https://material.angular.io/components/expansion/overview\#accordion) Accordion Multiple expansion-panels can be combined into an accordion. The `multi="true"` input allows the expansions state to be set independently of each other. When `multi="false"` (default) just one panel can be expanded at a given time: content\_copy ``` ``` ### [link](https://material.angular.io/components/expansion/overview\#lazy-rendering) Lazy rendering By default, the expansion panel content will be initialized even when the panel is closed. To instead defer initialization until the panel is open, the content should be provided as an `ng-template`: ```html This is the expansion title Some deferred content ``` ### [link](https://material.angular.io/components/expansion/overview\#accessibility) Accessibility `MatExpansionPanel` imitates the experience of the native `
` and `` elements. The expansion panel header applies `role="button"` and the `aria-controls` attribute with the content element's ID. Because expansion panel headers are buttons, avoid adding interactive controls as children of ``, including buttons and anchors. Overview Content Azure & Blue theme selected.
